item.title: Covid: Shops try to keep shelves stocked as more staff isolate
item.description: The government must "act fast" to avoid disruption to food supply, the British Retail Consortium says.

item.title: Charity, dating and pet spending booms, says Nationwide
item.description: People have been spending more on non-essentials as Covid restrictions ease, Nationwide says.

item.title: Bitcoin climbs as Elon Musk says Tesla 'likely' to accept it again
item.description: The firm had said in May it would no longer accept the cryptocurrency over environmental concerns.

item.title: Opioid crisis: US drug giants reach $26bn settlement
item.description: Four drug-makers and distributors have agreed to pay the sum to settle thousands of government lawsuits.

item.title: Nord Stream 2: US and Germany reach deal on controversial Russian gas pipeline
item.description: The US says the agreement prevents Russia from using the pipeline as a political weapon over Europe.

item.title: BP: Lorry driver shortages closing some sites temporarily
item.description: The oil firm says the "vast majority" of shortages were being "resolved within a day".

item.title: Fewer flat buyers to face pre-mortgage cladding checks, says Robert Jenrick
item.description: Lenders agree to change applications for loans involving buildings below 18m high, the government says.

item.title: 'Catastrophic' backlog at driving licence body, warns union
item.description: MPs are told bad decisions by DVLA managers resulted in a "catastrophic" processing backlog of 1.4 million cases.

item.title: NHS workers in England offered 3% pay rise
item.description: The offer is 2% more than was proposed in March, "in recognition of the unique impact of pandemic".

item.title: UK property sales at new record as boom peaks
item.description: Sales surged during June but analysts say the property boom has peaked as stamp duty holidays are withdrawn.

item.title: M&S to cut Christmas products in Northern Ireland
item.description: Chairman Archie Norman says customs checks will mean higher prices and less choice for customers.

item.title: Next shoppers splurge on summer clothes as weather heats up
item.description: The retailer upgrades profits forecast and repays some business rates relief after seeing a summer sales surge.

item.title: Gold attracts young investors trading online, says The Royal Mint
item.description: The Royal Mint records a rise in profits aided by a fivefold increase in gold investment by young adults.

item.title: UK borrowing leads to record interest payments
item.description: A surge in inflation means the government spent Â£8.7bn in interest payments last month.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'Four-day weeks are good for business'
item.description: CEO Joe Munns says giving his workers a three-day weekend makes them happier and more productive.

item.title: The little tech firm gunning for an airspeed record
item.description: Electroflight has built the E-NXT which it hopes will break the electric airspeed record.

item.title: Using plastic waste to help solve sand shortages
item.description: With construction sand in short supply crushed plastic is being used as an alternative.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'Don't sell your technology too early'
item.description: The CEO of an eco-friendly textiles firm advises holding out for the biggest customer you can find

item.title: Five ways for firms to reach customers with disabilities
item.description: Five ways to rethink how businesses can reach customers with disabilities.

item.title: Should we trust big tech with our health data?
item.description: Our medical records are in demand by tech firms who want to use the data to help tackle illnesses.
